by check mark whether the Registrant (1)&nbsp;has filed all reports required to

Registrant was required to file such reports), and (2)&nbsp;has been subject to
such filing requirements for the past 90 days.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; Yes&nbsp;</font><font size="1" face="Wingdings" style="font-family:Wingdings;font-size:9.0pt;">x</font><font size="1" style="font-size:9.0pt;">&nbsp;&nbsp; No&nbsp;</font><font size="1" face="Wingdings" style="font-family:Wingdings;font-size:9.0pt;">&#168;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">Indicate
by check mark whether the Registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined in
Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Act).&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; Yes&nbsp;</font><font size="1" face="Wingdings" style="font-family:Wingdings;font-size:9.0pt;">&#168;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:9.0pt;">&nbsp;&nbsp; No&nbsp;</font><font size="1" face="Wingdings" style="font-family:Wingdings;font-size:9.0pt;">x</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">At
July&nbsp;31, 2003, the aggregate market value of the Registrant&#146;s voting stock
held by nonaffiliates was approximately $234,422,189 (based upon the closing
price of the Common Stock at July&nbsp;31, 2003 as reported on the New York
Stock Exchange). The calculation of such market value has been made for the
purposes of this report only and should not be considered as an admission or
conclusion by the Registrant that any person is in fact an affiliate of the
Registrant.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">On July&nbsp;31, 2003, there were 31,849,811 shares of
Common Stock outstanding.</font></p>

  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="34" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:25.7pt;">
  <p align="right" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="87" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 2.</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="460" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:345.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Properties</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">

  <p align="right" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5</font></p>
  </td>

  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">

 <tr>
  <td width="87" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="87" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="460" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:345.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and
  Management</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="34" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:25.7pt;">
  <p align="right" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">53</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="87" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 13.</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="460" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:345.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain Relationships and Related Transactions</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="34" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:25.7pt;">
  <p align="right" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">54</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="87" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 14.</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="460" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:345.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Controls and Procedures</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="34" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:25.7pt;">
  <p align="right" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">54</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="87" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PART&nbsp;IV</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="460" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:345.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>

  <p align="right" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>

  <td width="87" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Item 15.</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="460" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:345.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules, and Reports
  on Form&nbsp;8-K</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:10.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>

  <td width="560" colspan="3" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:420.0pt;">

<p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">1</p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=2,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=506303,FOLIO='1',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]BG3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 13 21:18 2003' -->



<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PART&nbsp;I</font></b></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt 50.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-50.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 1.</font></b>&nbsp;&nbsp; BUSINESS <br>
(Dollars in thousands)</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AAR CORP. and its
subsidiaries are referred to herein collectively as &#147;AAR&#148; or &#147;the Company,&#148;
unless the context indicates otherwise. The Company was organized in 1955 as
the successor to a business founded in 1951 and was reincorporated in Delaware
in 1966. The Company is a leading independent provider of value-added products
and services to the worldwide aviation industry. The Company also markets and
sells certain of its products and services to the U.S. Government, including
various branches and agencies within the U.S. Military. The Company conducts
its business activities primarily through five principal operating
subsidiaries: AAR Parts Trading,&nbsp;Inc., AAR Aircraft&nbsp;&amp; Engine
Sales&nbsp;&amp; Leasing,&nbsp;Inc., AAR Distribution,&nbsp;Inc., AAR
Manufacturing,&nbsp;Inc., and AAR International,&nbsp;Inc. The Company&#146;s
international business activities are conducted primarily through AAR
International,&nbsp;Inc.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company reports its
activities in four business segments: (i)&nbsp;Inventory and Logistic Services,
comprised primarily of business activities conducted through AAR Parts Trading,&nbsp;Inc.
and AAR Distribution,&nbsp;Inc., (ii)&nbsp;Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul,
comprised primarily of business activities conducted through AAR Engine
Services,&nbsp;Inc. and AAR Allen Services,&nbsp;Inc., wholly-owned
subsidiaries of AAR Parts Trading,&nbsp;Inc. and AAR Distribution,&nbsp;Inc.,
respectively, (iii) Manufacturing, comprised primarily of business activities
conducted through AAR Manufacturing,&nbsp;Inc., and (iv)&nbsp;Aircraft and Engine
Sales and Leasing, comprised of business activities primarily conducted through
AAR Aircraft&nbsp;&amp; Engine Sales&nbsp;&amp; Leasing,&nbsp;Inc.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s Inventory
and Logistic Services segment activities include the purchase and sale of a
wide variety of new, overhauled and repaired engine parts and components and
airframe parts and components for the aviation aftermarket and military
customers. The Company also provides customized inventory supply and management
programs for engine and airframe parts and components in support of customer
maintenance activities. The Company is an authorized distributor for more than
150 leading aviation and aerospace product manufacturers. The Company acquires
aviation products for the Inventory and Logistic Services segment from domestic
and foreign airlines, independent aviation service companies, aircraft leasing
companies and original equipment manufacturers. In the Inventory and Logistic
Services segment, the majority of the Company&#146;s sales are made pursuant to
standard commercial purchase orders. In certain inventory supply and management
programs, the Company supplies products and services under agreements
reflecting negotiated terms and conditions.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segment
activities include the overhaul, repair and exchange of a wide variety of
airframe and engine parts and components for its commercial and military
customers. Repair and overhaul capabilities include most commercial aircraft
landing gear, a wide variety of avionics, instruments, electrical, electronic,
fuel, hydraulic and pneumatic components and a broad range of internal airframe
components. The Company also operates an aircraft maintenance facility
providing airframe maintenance, modification, special equipment installation,
painting services and aircraft terminal services for various models of
commercial, military, regional, business and general aviation aircraft. AAR
also operates an aircraft storage facility. The Company&#146;s repair and overhaul
of parts and components also support inventory management activities within the
Inventory and Logistic Services segment. AAR also provides turbine engine overhaul
and parts supply services to industrial gas and steam turbine operators. In the
Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segment, in addition to sales made under
standard commercial purchase orders, a portion of the segment&#146;s sales occur
pursuant to contracts under which the Company agrees to maintain, repair and
overhaul parts, components and whole aircraft. In the Maintenance, Repair and
Overhaul segment, the Company purchases replacement parts which are used in
various repair and overhaul operations primarily from original equipment
manufacturers and suppliers. The </font></p>

<font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:black;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;">
 <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">2</p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=3,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=1041798,FOLIO='2',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DE3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 05:19 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Company
has ongoing arrangements with certain original equipment manufacturers which
provide the Company access to parts, repair manuals and service bulletins in
support of the original equipment manufacturers&#146; parts. Although the terms of
each arrangement vary, they typically are made on standard original equipment
manufacturer terms as to duration, price and delivery. When possible, the
Company will obtain replacement parts used in repair and overhaul activities
from operating units in the Inventory and Logistic Services segment.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
Manufacturing segment activities include the design, manufacture and installation
of in-plane cargo loading and handling systems for commercial and military
aircraft and helicopters. The Company also designs and manufactures advanced
composite materials for commercial, business and military aircraft as well as
advanced composite structures for the transportation industry. In addition, the
Company manufactures and repairs a wide array of containers, pallets and shelters
in support of military and humanitarian tactical deployment activities. In the
Manufacturing segment, sales are made to customers pursuant to standard
commercial purchase orders and contracts. In the Manufacturing segment, the
Company purchases aluminum sheets, extrusions and castings and other necessary
supplies from a number of vendors.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s Aircraft and
Engine Sales and Leasing segment activities include the sale or lease of used
commercial jet aircraft and the sale or lease of a wide variety of new,
overhauled and repaired commercial jet engines. In the Aircraft and Engine
Sales and Leasing segment, each sale or lease is negotiated as a separate
agreement which includes term, price, representations, warranties and lease return
provisions. The Company&#146;s leases are fixed in regard to term; early termination
by the lessee is not permitted except in the event of a breach by the Company. In
the Aircraft and Engine Sales and Leasing segment, the Company purchases
aircraft and engines from domestic and foreign airlines, aircraft and engine
leasing companies and original equipment manufacturers. Within the Aircraft and
Engine Sales and Leasing segment, the Company also provides advisory services
which consists of records management, storage maintenance and assistance in
remarketing aircraft and engines.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has historically
been able to obtain raw materials and other items for its inventories for each
of its segments at competitive prices, terms and conditions from numerous
sources and expects to be able to continue to do so.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In the Inventory and
Logistic Services, Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul and Manufacturing segments,
the Company generally sells its products under standard 30 day terms. On
occasion, certain customers (principally foreign customers) will negotiate
extended payment terms (60-90 days). Except for customary warranty provisions,
customers do not have the right to return products nor do they have the right
to extended financing. In the Aircraft and Engine Sales and Leasing segment,
the Company sells its products on a cash due at delivery basis, standard 30 day
terms or on an extended term basis.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For each of its reportable segments, the Company
furnishes aviation products and services primarily through its own employees. The
principal customers for the Company&#146;s products and services in the Inventory
and Logistic Services and Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segments are
domestic and foreign commercial airlines, regional and commuter airlines,
business and general aviation operators, aviation original equipment
manufacturers, aircraft leasing companies, domestic and foreign military
organizations and independent aviation support companies. In the Manufacturing
segment, the Company&#146;s principal customers include domestic and foreign
military organizations, domestic and foreign commercial airlines, aviation original
equipment manufacturers and other industrial entities. The principal customers
in the Aircraft and Engine Sales and Leasing segment include domestic and
foreign commercial airlines and aircraft and engine finance and leasing
companies. Sales of aviation products and services to commercial airlines are
generally affected by such factors as the number, type and average age of
aircraft in service, the levels of aircraft utili</font></p>

<font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:black;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;">
 <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">3</p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=4,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=235996,FOLIO='3',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DE3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 05:19 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">zation
(e.g., frequency of schedules), the number of airline operators and the level
of sales of new and used aircraft.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has 13 Federal
Aviation Administration (FAA) licensed repair stations in the United States and
Europe. Of the 13 FAA repair stations, nine are also Joint Aviation Authorities
(JAA) licensed repair stations. Such licenses, which are ongoing in duration,
are required in order for the Company to perform authorized maintenance, repair
and overhaul services for its customers and are subject to revocation by the
government for non-compliance with applicable regulations. Of the 13 FAA
licensed repair stations, one is held in the Inventory and Logistics Services
segment, eight are held in the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segment, and
four are held in the Manufacturing segment. Of the nine JAA licensed repair stations,
eight are held in the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segment and one is held
in the Manufacturing segment. The Company believes that it possesses all
licenses and certifications that are material to the conduct of its business.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competition in the worldwide
aviation/aerospace industry is based on quality, ability to provide a broad
range of products and services, speed of delivery and price. Competitors in
both the Inventory and Logistic Services and the Maintenance, Repair and
Overhaul segments include original equipment manufacturers (including the
service divisions of large commercial airlines) and other independent suppliers
of parts and services. In certain activities of the Company&#146;s Aircraft and Engine
Sales and Leasing segment, the Company faces competition from financial
institutions, syndicators, commercial and specialized leasing companies and
other entities that provide financing. AAR&#146;s pallet, container and shelter
manufacturing activities in its Manufacturing segment compete with several
large and small companies, and its cargo systems competitors include a number
of divisions of large corporations. Although certain of the Company&#146;s
competitors have substantially greater financial and other resources than the
Company, in each of its four reportable segments AAR believes that it has
maintained a satisfactory competitive position through its responsiveness to
customer needs, its attention to quality and its unique combination of market
expertise and technical and financial capabilities.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At May&nbsp;31, 2003,
backlog believed to be firm was approximately $102,700 compared to $93,400 at May&nbsp;31,
2002. An additional $1,800 of unfunded government options on awarded contracts
also existed at May&nbsp;31, 2003. Approximately $99,100 of this backlog is expected
to be filled within the next 12 months. The increase in the Company&#146;s backlog
is due to increased orders in the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul,
Manufacturing and Inventory and Logistic Services segments.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At May&nbsp;31, 2003, the
Company employed approximately 2,100 persons worldwide.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales to the U.S.
Government, its agencies and its contractors were $170,191 (28.1% of total
sales), $163,173 (25.5% of total sales), and $139,072 (15.9% of total sales) in
fiscal years 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively. Because such sales are subject
to competitive bidding and government funding, no assurance can be given that
such sales will continue at levels previously experienced. The majority of the
Company&#146;s government contracts are for aviation products and services used for
ongoing routine military logistic support activities; unlike weapons systems
and other high-technology military requirements, these products and services
are less likely to be affected by significant changes in defense spending. The
Company&#146;s government contracts are subject to termination at the election of
the government; in the event of such a termination the Company would be
entitled to recover from the government all allowable costs incurred by the
Company through the date of termination.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For additional information
concerning the Company&#146;s business segments, see Item 7, &#147;Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; and &#147;Business
Segment Information&#148; in Note 14 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s internet
address is www.aarcorp.com. The Company makes available free of charge through
its web site its annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K, quarterly reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q,
current reports on Form&nbsp;8-K and all amendments to those reports filed or
furnished pursuant to Sec</font></p>

<font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:black;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;">
 <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">4</p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=5,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=172469,FOLIO='4',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DE3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 05:19 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">tion&nbsp;13(a)&nbsp;or
15(d)&nbsp;of the Exchange Act as soon as reasonably practicable after the
Company electronically files such material with, or furnishes such material to
the SEC. Information contained on the Company&#146;s web site is not a part of this
report.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 2.&nbsp;&nbsp; PROPERTIES</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s principal
activities in the Aircraft and Engine Sales and Leasing and Inventory and
Logistic Services segments are conducted from a building owned by the Company
in Wood Dale, Illinois, subject to a mortgage after July&nbsp;1, 2003. In
addition to warehouse space, this facility includes executive, sales and
administrative offices. The Company also leases facilities in Atlanta and
Macon, Georgia and Jacksonville, Florida to support activities in the Inventory
and Logistic Services segment.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Maintenance, Repair and
Overhaul activities are conducted in buildings owned by the Company located in
Garden City and Frankfort, New York; Windsor, Connecticut (subject to an
industrial revenue bond) and near Schiphol International Airport in The Netherlands.
This segment also conducts overhaul and repair activities in buildings leased
by the Company in Miami, Florida; London, England; Roswell, New Mexico; and
Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s activities
in the Manufacturing segment are conducted at facilities owned by the Company
in Clearwater, Florida (subject to an industrial revenue bond); and Cadillac
and Livonia, Michigan.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company believes that
its owned and leased facilities are suitable and adequate for its operational
requirements.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 3.&nbsp;&nbsp; LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Except as described below,
the Company is not a party to any material, pending legal proceeding (including
any governmental or environmental proceedings) other than routine litigation
incidental to its existing business.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AAR Manufacturing, Inc., a
subsidiary of the Company (&#147;subsidiary&#148;) received an Administrative Order for
Response Activity (&#147;Order&#148;) dated August&nbsp;7, 2003, from the Michigan
Department of Environmental Quality (&#147;MDEQ&#148;) relating to environmental
conditions at and in the vicinity of the subsidiary&#146;s Cadillac, Michigan plant.
The Order requires the subsidiary to perform environmental investigatory work,
prepare a feasibility study and a remedial action plan, and perform interim response
actions. The interim response actions include continuation of the response
activities the subsidiary is performing under a 1985 Consent Decree, operation
of a soil vapor extraction system the subsidiary had previously installed and
operated, determination of the need to provide alternate water supplies to
off-site properties (and if it is so determined then to actually provide it),
removal of any free phase liquids encountered in the ground, providing notices
of groundwater contamination migration to off-site property owners, and other
actions determined by the MDEQ or the subsidiary to be appropriate. A letter
dated June&nbsp;14, 2002 from the MDEQ further demands payment of environmental
response costs already incurred by the MDEQ in the amount of $525 plus interest
plus unspecified costs to be incurred in the future by the MDEQ. The Order and
the letter which accompanies the Order threaten the imposition of civil fines
up to $25 for each day of violation of the Order plus exemplary damages up to
three times the costs incurred by the MDEQ if the subsidiary does not comply
with the Order. The Order may require the implementation of the remedial action
plan although it is not clear on that point. The Order requires the
implementation of emergency response action if a release of hazardous
substances, threat of a release, or exacerbation of existing contamination
occurs during the pendency of the Order.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The subsidiary is evaluating
its defenses to the allegations in the letter and to the Order, including the defense
that the 1985 Consent Decree entered into with the State previously resolved
most of the claims now asserted by the State and which are the basis for much
of the Order. It is </font></p>

<font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:black;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;">
 <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">5</p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=6,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=126486,FOLIO='5',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DE3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 05:19 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">not possible
at this stage to determine the expenditures that may be required in connection
with this matter. The subsidiary has received some funds from an insurance
carrier to reimburse it for work done by the subsidiary under the 1985 Consent
Decree and will seek further coverage for the matters in the June&nbsp;14, 2002
MDEQ letter and the Order. The subsidiary, prior to the issuance of the Order,
sought a Court order to enforce the 1985 Consent Decree but that relief was
denied by the Court, primarily on the basis that the action was premature since
the State was not pursuing an enforcement action at the time. The subsidiary
has sought leave to appeal that decision to the Michigan Court of Appeals.</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:11.0pt;">ITEM 4.</font></b>&nbsp;&nbsp; SUBMISSION OF
MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No matter was submitted to
a vote of security holders during the fourth quarter of the fiscal year covered
by this report.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Supplemental Item:</font></b></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANT</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Information concerning each
executive officer of the Company is set forth below:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

</table>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Mr.&nbsp;Storch</font></b>
has been President of the Company since 1989 and Chief Executive Officer since
1996. Previously, he was Chief Operating Officer from 1989 to 1996 and a Vice
President of the Company from 1988 to 1989. Mr.&nbsp;Storch joined the Company
in 1979 and was president of a major subsidiary from 1984 to 1988. Mr.&nbsp;Storch
has been a director of the Company since 1989. Mr.&nbsp;Storch is Ira A.
Eichner&#146;s son-in-law. Mr.&nbsp;Eichner is Chairman of the Board and a Director
of the Company.</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Mr.&nbsp;Pulsifer</font></b>
has been Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of the Company since
1990. Previously he served as Vice President (since 1990) and General Counsel
(since 1987). He was previously with United Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. for 14 years,
most recently as Senior Counsel.</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Mr.&nbsp;Romenesko</font></b>
has been Vice President and Chief Financial Officer since 1994. Previously he
served as Controller of the Company from 1991 to 1995 and in various other
positions since joining the Company in 1981.</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Mr.&nbsp;Clark</font></b>
has been Group Vice President, Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul since 2000. Previously
he was General Manager of AAR Aircraft Component Services &#151; Amsterdam from 1995
to 2000 and in various other positions since joining the Company in 1982.</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Mr.&nbsp;Sharp</font></b>
has been Vice President and Controller, Chief Accounting Officer since 1999. Previously
he served as Controller of the Company from 1996 to 1999. Prior to joining the
Company he was with Kraft Foods from 1994 to 1996, and with KPMG LLP from 1984
to 1994, most recently as audit senior manager.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Each executive officer is
elected annually by the Board of Directors at the first meeting of the Board
held after the annual meeting of stockholders. Executive officers continue to
hold office until their successors are duly elected or until their death,
resignation, termination or reassignment.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">6</p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=7,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=503721,FOLIO='6',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DE3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 05:19 2003' -->



<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PART&nbsp;II</font></b></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 49.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-49.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 5.</font></b>&nbsp;&nbsp; MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON EQUITY AND
RELATED <br>
STOCKHOLDER MATTERS <br>
(Dollars in thousands, except per share amounts)</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s Common Stock is traded on the New York
Stock Exchange and the Chicago Stock Exchange. On July&nbsp;31, 2003 there were
approximately 7,500 holders of the Company&#146;s Common Stock, including
participants in security position listings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of the Company&#146;s financing arrangements
contain provisions restricting the payment of dividends or repurchase of its
shares. See Note 3 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included
herein. Under the most restrictive of these provisions, the Company may not pay
dividends (other than stock dividends) or acquire its capital stock if, after
giving effect to the aggregate amounts paid on or after June&nbsp;1, 1995, such
amounts exceed the sum of $20,000 plus 50% of Consolidated Net Income (Loss) of
the Company after June&nbsp;1, 1994. The Company is currently prohibited from
paying dividends or purchasing its shares pursuant to this provision.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
table below sets forth for each quarter of the fiscal year indicated the
reported high and low market prices of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on the New
York Stock Exchange and the quarterly dividends declared. The Company suspended
payment of dividends in October&nbsp;2002.</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:21.3pt;">

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 51.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-51.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 6.</font></b>&nbsp;&nbsp; SELECTED

(In thousands, except per share amounts)</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"></p>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;">

</font></div>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;">Notes:</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.15pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:justify;text-indent:-20.15pt;"><sup><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1</font></sup><sup><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></sup>In
connection with certain long-term inventory management programs, the Company purchased
factory-new products on behalf of its customers from original equipment manufacturers.
These products were purchased from the manufacturer and &#147;passed through&#148; to the
Company&#146;s customers at the Company&#146;s cost. In December&nbsp;2000, these
inventory management programs were discontinued.</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.15pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:justify;text-indent:-20.15pt;"><sup><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></sup><sup><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></sup>In
February&nbsp;2002, the Company sold 5,010 shares of common stock for $34,334,
net of expenses.</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 20.15pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:justify;text-indent:-20.15pt;"><sup><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3</font></sup><sup><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></sup>See
Note 2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for a discussion regarding
impairment and special charges recorded during fiscal 2003 and fiscal 2002.</p>

<font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:black;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;">
 <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">8</p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=9,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=403883,FOLIO='8',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DG3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 15:29 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 50.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-50.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 7.</font></b>&nbsp;&nbsp; MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS<br>
(Dollars in thousands)</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Factors Which May&nbsp;Affect
Future Results</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s future
operating results and financial position may be adversely affected or fluctuate
substantially on a quarterly basis as a result of continuing difficulties in
the commercial aviation environment exacerbated by the September&nbsp;11, 2001
terrorist attacks and the events that followed, the relatively weak worldwide
economic climate and other factors, including:&#160;
(1)&nbsp;decline in demand for the Company&#146;s products and services and
the ability of the Company&#146;s customers to meet their financial obligations to
the Company, particularly in light of the weakened financial condition of many
of the world&#146;s commercial airlines; (2)&nbsp;the potential risk for declining
market values for aviation products and equipment caused by various factors,
including the bankruptcies of&#160; United
Airlines, US Airways,&nbsp;Inc., Air Canada, Avianca,&nbsp;Inc. and Hawaiian
Airlines,&nbsp;Inc., possible future airline bankruptcies and other factors
within the airline industry; (3)&nbsp;difficulties in re-leasing or selling
aircraft and engines that are currently being leased on a long- or short-term
basis; (4)&nbsp;lack of assurance that sales to the U.S. Government, its
agencies and its contractors (which were 28.1% of total sales in fiscal 2003),
will continue at levels previously experienced, since such sales are subject to
competitive bidding and government funding; (5)&nbsp;access to the debt and
equity capital markets and the ability to draw down under financing agreements,
which may be limited in light of industry conditions and Company performance; (6)&nbsp;changes
in or noncompliance with laws and regulations that may affect certain of the
Company&#146;s aviation related activities that are subject to licensing,
certification and other regulatory requirements imposed by the FAA and other
regulatory agencies, both domestic and foreign; (7)&nbsp;competition from other
companies, including original equipment manufacturers, some of which have
greater financial resources than the Company; (8)&nbsp;exposure to product
liability and property claims that may be in excess of the Company&#146;s substantial
liability insurance coverage; (9)&nbsp;difficulties in being able to
successfully integrate business acquisitions and (10)&nbsp;the outcome of any
pending or future material litigation or environmental proceedings.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Critical Accounting
Policies and Significant Estimates</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements are
prepared in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the
United States. Management of the Company has made estimates and assumptions
relating to the reporting of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent
liabilities to prepare the consolidated financial statements. The most significant
estimates made by management of the Company include adjustments to reduce the
value of inventories and equipment on or available for lease, allowance for
doubtful accounts and loss accruals for aviation equipment operating leases. Accordingly,
actual results could differ materially from those estimates. The following is a
summary of the accounting policies considered critical by management of the
Company.</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Allowance
for Doubtful Accounts</font></i></font><i><font style="font-style:italic;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </font></i>The
Company&#146;s allowance for doubtful accounts is intended to reduce the value of
customer accounts receivable to amounts expected to be collected. In determining
the required allowance, the Company considers factors such as general and industry-specific
economic conditions, customer credit history, and the customer&#146;s current and
expected future financial performance.</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Inventories</font></i></font><i><font style="font-style:italic;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </font></i>Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
Cost is determined by the specific identification, average cost or first-in,
first-out methods. Provisions are made for excess and obsolete inventories and
inventories that have been impaired as a result of industry conditions. The
Company has utilized certain assumptions when determining the market value of
inventories, such as historical sales of inventory, current and expected future
aviation usage trends, replacement val</p>

<font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:black;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;">
 <p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">9</p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=10,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=457305,FOLIO='9',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DG3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 15:29 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ues and expected future
demand. Principally as a result of the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11,
2001 and its anticipated impact on the global airline industry&#146;s financial
condition, fleet size and aircraft utilization, the Company recorded a significant
charge for impaired inventories during the second quarter of fiscal 2002
utilizing those assumptions. During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2003, the
Company recorded an additional charge as a result of a further decline in
market value for these inventories. Reductions in demand for certain of the
Company&#146;s inventories or declining market values, as well as differences
between actual results and the assumptions utilized by the Company when
determining the market value of its inventories, could result in additional
impairment charges in future periods.</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Equipment
on or Available for Lease</font></i></font><i><font style="font-style:italic;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </font></i>Lease
revenue is recognized as earned. The cost of the asset under lease is original
purchase price plus overhaul costs. Depreciation is computed using the
straight-line method over the estimated service life of the equipment, and
maintenance costs are expensed as incurred. The balance sheet classification is
based on the lease term, with fixed-term leases less than twelve months
classified as short-term and all others classified as long-term.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting
Standards No.&nbsp;144 (SFAS No.&nbsp;144), &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or
Disposal of Long-lived Assets,&#148; the Company is required to test for impairment
of long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the
carrying value of an asset may not be recoverable from its undiscounted cash
flows. When applying the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;144 to equipment on or
available for lease, the Company has utilized certain assumptions when
estimating future undiscounted cash flows, such as current and estimated future
lease rates, estimated residual values and expected future demand. Differences
between actual results and the assumptions utilized by the Company when
determining undiscounted cash flows could result in future impairments of
equipment on or available for lease.</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Aviation Equipment
Operating Leases</font></i></font><i><font style="font-style:italic;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </font></i>The
Company from time to time leases aviation equipment (engines and aircraft) from
lessors under arrangements that are classified by the Company as operating leases.
The Company may also sublease the aviation equipment to a customer on a short-
or long-term basis. The terms of the operating leases in which the Company is
the lessee are one year with options to renew annually at the election of the
Company. If the Company elects not to renew a lease or the lease term expires,
the Company will purchase the equipment from the lessor at its scheduled
purchase option price. The terms of the lease agreements also allow the Company
to purchase the equipment at any time during a lease at its scheduled purchase
option price. In those instances in which the Company anticipates that it will
purchase aviation equipment and that the scheduled purchase option price will
exceed estimated undiscounted cash flows related to the equipment, the Company
records an accrual for loss. The Company has utilized certain assumptions when
estimating future undiscounted cash flows, such as current and estimated future
lease rates, estimated residual values, and expected future demand. Differences
between actual results and the assumptions utilized by the Company when
determining undiscounted cash flows could result in future provisions for
losses on aviation equipment under operating leases.</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.1pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Results of
Operations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company reports its activities in four business
segments: Inventory and Logistic Services; Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul;
Manufacturing; and Aircraft and Engine Sales and Leasing.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales in the Inventory and Logistic Services segment
are derived from the sale of a wide variety of new, overhauled and repaired
engine and airframe parts and components to the commercial aviation and
military markets, as well as the distribution of new airframe parts purchased
from various original equipment manufacturers and sold to commercial and general
aviation customers. Cost of sales consists principally of the cost of product
(primarily aircraft and engine parts) and overhead (primarily indirect labor,
facility cost and insurance).</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;">10</p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="black" align="center">

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=11,EFW="2116671",CP="AAR CORP",DN="1",CHK=924690,FOLIO='10',FILE="DISK020:[03CHI1.03CHI3951.EDGAR]DG3951A.CHC",USER="MWEINST",CD='Aug 15 15:29 2003' -->



<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
 <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales in the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul segment
are derived from the repair and overhaul of a wide range of commercial and
military aircraft engine and airframe parts, landing gear and components;
aircraft maintenance and storage; and the repair, overhaul and sale of parts
for industrial gas and steam turbine operators. Cost of sales consists principally
of cost of product (primarily replacement aircraft parts), direct labor and
overhead.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales in the Manufacturing segment are derived from
the manufacture and sale of a wide array of containers, pallets and shelters
used to support the U.S. Military&#146;s tactical deployment requirements, in-plane
cargo loading and handling systems for commercial and military applications and
advanced composite materials and components for aerospace and industrial use. Cost
of sales consists principally of the cost of product, direct labor and
overhead.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales in the Aircraft and Engine Sales and Leasing
segment are derived from the sale and lease of commercial aircraft and engines
and technical and advisory services. Cost of sales consists principally of cost
of product (aircraft and engines), labor and the cost of lease revenue
(primarily depreciation, lease expense and insurance).</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:justify;text-indent:20.15pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
table below sets forth consolidated sales for the Company&#146;s four business
segments for each of the last three fiscal years ended May&nbsp;31.</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="57" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">216,727</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="57" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">257,117</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="333" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:249.75pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 20.15pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Manufacturing</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="57" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">119,871</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">99,558</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">

 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF">
  <td width="333" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:249.75pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 20.15pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Aircraft and Engine Sales and Leasing</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="57" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">34,769</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="57" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">64,369</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="57" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">132,826</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="333" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:249.75pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.1pt;text-indent:-10.1pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="50" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:37.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">606,337</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="50" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:37.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">638,721</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="50" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:37.45pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">853,659</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
